content.body: annevk: Intentional or accidental that the URL Standard supports full-width characters for IPv4 but not for IPv6?
content.formatted_body: annevk: Intentional or accidental that the URL Standard supports full-width characters for IPv4 but not for IPv6?

content.body: hsivonen: Intentional. Supporting them for IPv4 is not desired, but it's the outcome of only being able to distinguish between domains and IPv4 addresses late. For the same reason IPv4 supports %31 and such, but IPv6 does not.
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: Intentional. Supporting them for IPv4 is not desired, but it's the outcome of only being able to distinguish between domains and IPv4 addresses late. For the same reason IPv4 supports %31 and such, but IPv6 does not.

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> hsivonen: Intentional. Supporting them for IPv4 is not desired, but it's the outcome of only being able to distinguish between domains and IPv4 addresses late. For the same reason IPv4 supports %31 and such, but IPv6 does not.

OK. Thanks. Let's see what I break by removing full-width IPv6 support from Gecko...
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
hsivonen: Intentional. Supporting them for IPv4 is not desired, but it's the outcome of only being able to distinguish between domains and IPv4 addresses late. For the same reason IPv4 supports %31 and such, but IPv6 does not.
OK. Thanks. Let's see what I break by removing full-width IPv6 support from Gecko...

content.body: Hi I would like to create a proposal form HTML, `<input mask="0000-0000-0000-0000">`. Sadly I am not sure how to do so. Do I create a repository? Is there a template for proposal repository?
content.formatted_body: Hi I would like to create a proposal form HTML, <input mask="0000-0000-0000-0000">. Sadly I am not sure how to do so. Do I create a repository? Is there a template for proposal repository?

content.body: Does anyone know off the top of their head whether an element's children changed steps (https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-node-children-changed-ext) are called by the HTML parser? In Chromium and WebKit the function receives an argument to differentiate between parser and API (JS) but the DOM spec doesn't pass an argument.

* Does anyone know off the top of their head whether an element's children changed steps (https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-node-children-changed-ext) are called by the HTML parser? In Chromium and WebKit the function receives an argument to differentiate between parser and API (JS) but the DOM spec doesn't pass an argument. So I'm wondering if this distinction isn't needed in the spec because it's not actually called by the parser?

m.new_content.body: Does anyone know off the top of their head whether an element's children changed steps (https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-node-children-changed-ext) are called by the HTML parser? In Chromium and WebKit the function receives an argument to differentiate between parser and API (JS) but the DOM spec doesn't pass an argument. So I'm wondering if this distinction isn't needed in the spec because it's not actually called by the parser?

content.body: Luke Warlow: it's called by the parser as things stand today
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: it's called by the parser as things stand today

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Luke Warlow: it's called by the parser as things stand today

Okay thanks. Time to work out a plan B for detecting JS changes.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Luke Warlow: it's called by the parser as things stand today
Okay thanks. Time to work out a plan B for detecting JS changes.

content.body: If I put some work into upstreaming DOM Parser to the HTML spec would it be prefered as one larger PR, or multiple smaller ones?
